user_location: of Treadwell Park Washington, Washington DC
review_blob: Translucent golden hued orange with a massive puffy white head that leaves globs of lace as it slowly fades. The aroma has a distinct basement note that mingles well with overtones of bubblegum Belgian ale yeast and European pilsner malt sulfur. Presence of alcohol is increasing with temperature. The flavour has above average sweetness while staying lean enough to have a mature, airy, medium-full palate. Bottle conditioning is absolutely evident. True to style phenolic presence, an airy mouthfeel, flawless appearance and a long, fruity finish make this a memorable one.

user_location: of Treadwell Park Washington, Washington DC
review_blob: Hazy pale gold pour at brewery. Pleasant lactic acid laden aroma with notes of canned pineapple, tart red strawberry, fleshy tropical citrus. The flavour leads way to more funky, dirty sourness. There may be trace amounts of caproic acid here, though not enough to be unpleasant. The gentle carbonation for the style allows the fuller body of this beverage to seem more full than it is. This was thoroughly enjoyable.

user_location: of Treadwell Park Washington, Washington DC
review_blob: Clear pale gold pour with a two finger whispy white head that fades slowly to a ring. The nose is of honeyed doughy pale malt, floral noble hops and a hint of Pilsner malt sulfur. The aroma is rounded and enticing, hinting at the maturity if this fine brew. The flavour is simple and mild, though in no way insipid. Spicy hops balance the appropriately bready, lightly cracker-like malts. Very little sulfur in the flavour. The palate is crisp and dry, allowing the drinker to enjoy with minimal time between sips. The finish is medium long and spicy. Cisco is killing it lately

user_location: of Treadwell Park Washington, Washington DC
review_blob:
As a pro brewer and certified cicerone, I can assure you the low score here is bs. People love to hate gimmick beers, but a gimmick beer with true pedigree like this deserves praise. The peppermint and dark chocolate complex in the flavour is not as presumptuous as other examples, though it retains the character it advertises to have. Its refreshing and straight forward with some light caramel sweetness. Its relatively dry and drying in the finish, which compels the drinker to go for the next sip right away. It has a cooling, lasting minty aftertaste without being medicinal. I found the overall composition and balance to have a harmonious flavour and aroma. There is enough hop presence to give the beer proper structure on the palate. 
While I thoroughly enjoyed this, I can offer up two criticisms. I would like a slightly fuller mouthfeel with a slightly slicker texture, as well as more yeast flavour. Im guessing they uses Cali ale yeast, which almost completely neutral.
beer_name: Flying Dog Brewhouse Rarities: Mint Chocolate Stout

user_location: of Treadwell Park Washington, Washington DC
review_blob: Above average American wheat ale. Slightly hazy bright orange pour with a two finger head that fades quickly to a ring. Pleasant aroma dominated by amarillo tangerine and orange zest, as well as mango and a bready wheat backbone that struggles to surface. Up front, the flavour mostly suggests hop flavour, but not much bitterness. Low astringency in this hoppy brew. Creamy, tropical-fruity mid-palate taste with a short-lived finish of lemony and orange citrus and fresh baked bread. The short palate duration makes this one good beer; not a great beer. While I may not feel the need to purchase this again, as there are just so many examples of such hoppy session ales, I cant imagine ever turning one down. The bitterness is low enough to play well with food, which is nice. I will be pairing this with tofu tempura in a mango-yellow curry sauce.

user_location: of Treadwell Park Washington, Washington DC
review_blob: Very disappointed here. Maybe the shelf life is vey low, and at nearly a year in the bottle, this one just went bad. I wrongfully assumed that this beer would improve with age, maybe up to a couple years. The aroma is heavily tainted by oxidation off-flavour compounds, as well as murky swamp water and misplaced strong minerality. Tastes like armature homebrew. The apricot is mostly lost behind a slew of off-flavours. No real tartness is perceivable. There is an astringency in the finish, with a slight phenolic bitterness resembling chalky textured-pill form medications. The appearance isnt great either. The short lived fizzy heady atop a hazy amber colour is certainly not inviting. I will need to try their other beers closer to their bottled-on date.

user_location: of Treadwell Park Washington, Washington DC
review_blob: Pours a crystal clear yellow gold. Minimal head and minimal retention. The nose is very complex, with leather, stone fruits, brett, muscavato grape, and light alcohol. The flavour has more pronounced booze, especially (obviously) as it warms. Its similar to prosecco in flavour and and body, with a more velvety texture and firmer tannin structure. Flavours linger for a while, though its still really dry. 11% is well hidden. Great stuff!

user_location: of Treadwell Park Washington, Washington DC
review_blob: Be prepared to have your brain melted! This sak is, as described on the bottle, very much like an Trocken Riesling, but an unfinished one. Tart is apparent in the aroma, along with Taro, green apple skin and wet stone. Very pleasant tartness is unexpected and amazing! Its almost funny its so enjoyable. Green apple, silt, rich rice and gentle citrus come to mind while tasting. The palate is full yet clean; slick and warming. This is a sak to behold!

user_location: of Treadwell Park Washington, Washington DC
review_blob: Very high quality daiginjo. Nearly colorless and completely clear, it looks as it should. The nose is ripe with sticky rice, melon and wispy flowers. The flavour is incredibly clean, though because if its slick, full bodied palate, the flavours linger for quite a while. The alcohol is sweet and warming, not harsh and off-putting. Delicious, rich sweet rice dominates. There is a very low minerality, so stoney flavours are not really apparent. Clean, yet rich and sweet. Balanced nicely. I would certainly purchase this again.

user_location: of Treadwell Park Washington, Washington DC
review_blob: Poured into a Domaine Dupont flute. Pale copper colour suggests a strong tannin structure. Highly effervescent, with minimal gushing upon opening. A rocky head takes nearly a minute to fully settle in the flute. The aroma excites impressions of fall spice (nutmeg mostly), leather, some barnyard funk and heavy tannin. This is one of the closest American replications of a Normandy cidre Ive come across. The flavour is high in tannins and and low in acidity. Booze is hardly detectable. Delicate spice is in the forefront throughout. The only shortfall here is the lack of palate duration and body. It comes across a tad lean for the "style." Nice spritzy, sharp effervescent carbonation. A very mature Oregon cider!

user_location: of Treadwell Park Washington, Washington DC
review_blob: 750ml bottle, white wine glass. Pours out a very hazy sunset orange with a sudsy white head. Not much lacing. Intoxicating levels of white grapes and vanilla oak with dirty brettanomyces overtones. High levels of bitterness up front and throughout, far after the finish. There is a citric acidity that mingles well with the bretty filth. The alcohol is relatively well-hidden, but definitely apparent most in the finish. Tannic oaked Chardonnay notes and hop bitterness dominate the aftertaste. Mellow carbonation and an airy body. Nice, but not as overwhelming as I was expecting.
beer_name: Anchorage Bitter Monk Belgian Style Double IPA

user_location: of Treadwell Park Washington, Washington DC
review_blob: 750ml to the face, white wine glass. Pours a murky sandstone colour with a frothy beige head that retains well and shows good cling as the head fades. The nose is rustic, dusty and full of oak character. The grape notes to me come across almost more like a pinot grigio than a chardonnay, but whatever, still bright, pungent and enticing. Oh man this is tasty! On the palate, oak and peppery notes stay in the forefront while on the back end, a lingering of vanilla and wine notes suggestive of Gurwitz Terminer. I could imagine this beer being equally tasty in a different, less earthy and funky way without the B. brux, and possibly more quaffable, but its great as is. Passion fruit and complex citrus notes emerge with greater presence as it warms. All the intermingling flavours and aromas are delicately balanced, yet the overall network of zesty citrus, peppercorn, funk, oak and saison yeast filth is one of tremendous intensity. The finish is slightly astringent, though this is characteristic of the blend of stains employed and only adds to the dryness of the finish, making the beer effectively more quenching and sessionable (if only I could afford this as an everyday session ale *sigh*). The mouthfeel is velvety, even moreso as it warms, with lively carbonation and a long duration. If only all things to come from Alaska were this awesome.

user_location: of Treadwell Park Washington, Washington DC
review_blob: 12oz bottle,  Stlzle snifter. Pours a deep mahogany to chestnut colour with a 1-finger, sudsy bronze head that fades to a spotty film. Overripe light and stone fruits, toffee, and honey dominate the aroma with some heat just barely poking through. The flavour brings forth a soft sweetness with loads of honey dextrin complexity and dark pitted fruit. Medium/thin bodied with a creamy mouthfeel and soft carbonation. The finish leaves impressions of lighter fruits than experienced in the flavour. Minimal, floral hop presence throughout. A nice winter warming beer that does very well to hide the presence of alcohol. Would love to age some bottles and see how the complex sugars morph the beer into something even more savory. Nice job, Weyerbacher! Deserving of GABF recognition.

user_location: of Treadwell Park Washington, Washington DC
review_blob: Bottle, poured into dry, clean Peroni lager glass, producing a hazy pale amber colour with a dense, though thin, beige head that has very little cling and retention. Soft noble hop aroma of a pear/red apple kind of complex accompanying the familiar floral notes. Flavour is sweet, yet dry in the finish, with sweet cereal grain up front, doughy malt, a tasteful amount of DMS throughout, and floral, herbal hops. A bit of heat is allowed to poke through in the finish as its so dry, as is a minerally note that reminds me of iron, which, if Im detecting this properly, is actually oxidized polypeptides, which seems unlikely. Very palatable with medium carbonation and fine bubbles. A pretty enjoyable Zwickle that I would order on draft at a biergarten, though for the price, would not get in bottles again.

user_location: of Treadwell Park Washington, Washington DC
review_blob: Bottle ordered at CKDC. Date on bottle is March of 08 and sampled today. Deep mahogany colour with a late-forming 1-finger beige head. The nose is similar to what you might expect from an English barleywine. British noble hops, vinous malts, brown sugar, juniper (duh), dried dark pitted fruits, and mild cocoa impressions. A bit more of the cocoa and brown sugary sweetness are apparent upon the first sip. Grassy and herbal hop notes, tobacco, juniper and figs/dates/dried dark fruit. The palate could be a little fuller, IMO, though the duration is long. Im glad to have sampled this tasty brew. Kudos to Huvila and CKDC!

user_location: of Treadwell Park Washington, Washington DC
review_blob: 12oz bottle poured into a snifter. Hazy orange colour with a minimal, but fine, slightly off-white head that fades to a sudsy film and complete ring at the edges. The aroma immediately impressed me with subtle, tasteful Belgian yeast esters. Not too much bubblegum or apple esters. The aroma benefits from a subdued, enticing malty presence and minimal herbal and floral hops. As anticipated, bubblegum yeasty notes and green apple dominated the flavor profile, though not to its detriment. The addition of lush caramel and candi sugar sweetness accompanied by strong vanilla overtones makes this a tasty desert brew. The finish is certainly warming and more drying and airy than many other American interpretations of the style. The tasty esters and potent phenols linger for some time, supported by the fuller, malty body. My only complaint about this, when comparing it to the highly regarded classic examples, are the lack of effervescence and a rocky white head and it is perhaps a bit syrupy. Otherwise I found this to be very enjoyable and dangerously drinkable for 10% abv. Kudos River Horse! Glad to have you guys as a local (sorta) brewery.

user_location: of Treadwell Park Washington, Washington DC
review_blob: On tap at Churchkey, DC (full pour). Completely black with a solid mocha head. The nose gives the impression its going to be cloyingly sweet, and there is certainly licorice there. Massive amounts of anise, but lucky for me, I like that stuff! The mint ads an interesting tinge to the whole profile. Some rich caramel malt and woody notes are there to back it up. Not much perceivable bourbon here. The flavour is just as advertised, and not cloying. Pleasant actually. Very! This beer wasnt getting too much love from my friends who also tried it and a couple members of the staff, but I dug it. Chewy mouthfeel with a velvety texture and long palate duration, coating tooth and gum. Not something Id like to drink a lot of, but one is definitely appreciated. Great job, Shorts! Stay weird!

user_location: of Treadwell Park Washington, Washington DC
review_blob: 12oz bottle, nonic pint. Pours translucent deep brown, almost black colour with mahogany edges. Nice frothy tan head that leaves beautiful concentric rings of lacing.The nose is a bit muted for having something as aromatic as vanilla in it, but the vanilla is certainly perceivable, being the dominant aroma. There is also some soft caramel, toasty malt and some unsavory hard mineral notes. The flavour is completely unoffensive, but a bit dull. The body is too thin and the mouthfeel is quite as creamy and/or oily as I like my porters. Hops completely take a back seat in this brew to the vanilla, caramel malt and mild cocoa notes. The vanilla in the rather abrupt finish is a bit hollow and without a sticky, longer malty finish that it would need to back it up. It almost tastes plastic-like. Hard to explain.

user_location: of Treadwell Park Washington, Washington DC
review_blob: 12oz bottle pours nearly clear deep gold into a tulip. Thick sheets of lacing left with each sip even after the off-white, creamy head fades to a small ring. The nose is similar to a nice helles bock with a tad more hop citrus and grass. The malts come across as lightly toasty and bready, suggesting a sweet flavour to come. Very sweet light malty, bready flavour with pleasant bitterness that is still a bit low for a double pils, and not really very "noble." Some doughy flavours accompany. Tastes more like American variety noble heritage hops were used. Not much heat at all here, but at 7% abv, that makes sense. Tasteful, perceivable amount of DMS lets you know its a pilsner without tasting like a corny, cooked veggie bomb. Soft melon/honeydew fruitiness, almost like a Jolly Rancher? Yea, thats it! The mouthfeel is slick up front, gently carbonated given the style, and full-bodied, almost syrupy in the finish. Very sweet, but enough hops are there to keep it from being cloying.

user_location: of Treadwell Park Washington, Washington DC
review_blob: Packaged 8/15/11 at Brewery Ommegang. 750ml bottle. Poured into a 0.3L Unibroue tulip, producing a translucent honey/orange colour with a dense, but thin, white head that fades quickly and leaves almost no lacing. Standard Belgian blond aroma of bubblegum yeast, clove, green apple, pear, clementine-like citrus flesh and candy sweet light malts. The flavour is a little green in my opinion, with some dusty, basement yeasty notes. Apple and bubblegum esters dominate with some heat coming from the booze mid-palate. The presence of the high abv does not linger in the finish. Slick mouthfeel and medium-bodied. The finish brings some herbal hop bitterness along with a touch of medicinal astringency. Herbal, spicy noble hops become more apparent as the initial shock from the sweetness fades. Softer carbonation compared to other great examples of strong Belgian blonde ales. I dont even want to know how green this beer would be if brewed at Brasserie DAChouffe, especially since theyve started cutting tank time to 6 days for some beers!!!! To me, this beer is uninspired and nothing new for either brewery. Its just this mellow, clovey, ester-bomb. I must say it is well-executed and tasteful, as are all beers from Ommegang, but this really did not excite me. Id take any beer in Ommegangs regular line-up over this.

user_location: of Treadwell Park Washington, Washington DC
review_blob: Pint can poured into a bubble pint. Pours a murky orange/rust colour with a dense frothy head that clings to the glass, leaving concentric rings of foamy lace with each sip. Large flecks of sediment immediately sink to the bottom. The nose packs an incredible amount of fresh hoppy volatiles. Grapefruit aroma is overwhelming with some zesty, citrus rind and pine as well. Even some passion fruit notes are perceivable. Nuclear hop bomb! Velvety texture in the mouthfeel up front, followed by a highly attenuated, thinner finish, allowing the hop zest, spice and citrus acidity to shine without too much malt interfering. The flavour brings out more of the tropical citrus aromatic qualities, along with some light maltiness that is not overly sweet, which tends to be a problem with many double IPAs out there. Bitter, resinous finish gives you the desired hop hop assault without astringency. The finish is not terribly long, but it is tasty and drying, making this a highly poundable brewski. Could possibly use more carbonation, but if you take the suggestion written on the top of the can, which is to "DRINK FROM THE CAN!", then its possible that it may not have needed more carbonation given that method of serving. This was truly a pleasure. So dank, so fresh!

user_location: of Treadwell Park Washington, Washington DC
review_blob: 750ml poured into a tulip.  Massive, rocky off-white head sitting atop a nearly translucent orange body like a mass of whipped cream. Globs of lacing left with each sip. The aroma is typical of a Stillwater saison with a very dusty "rustic" profile with passion fruit, peach and a smorgasbord yeasty esters galore! The flavour is dry, semi-sweet, mildly salty and supah fruity. Booze is extremely well-hidden. Airy and medium carbonation that is somehow very spritzy tactically. Medium palate duration with lingering spicy, yeasty notes akin to white peppercorn and bubblegum. Delish!
beer_name: Stillwater / Mikkeller Two Gypsies Our Side

user_location: of Treadwell Park Washington, Washington DC
review_blob: Pint bottle. Snifter. Poured out much lighter in colour than I remembered, now being in a well lit apartment. Nearly clear rust orange colour with a minimal, scummy looking white head. Whatever, I bet this has been sitting on the shelf for some time. An intense smolder overwhelms the aroma, with some red pitted fruits mostly hidden in the background. A bit of licorice, perhaps even a bit of cherry cough syrup impressions come through, as well. The flavour is everything I expected from the nose. Thin bodied and not as severely smokey as the original rauch. Slick in mouthfeel, almost oily and gently carbonated. Earthy notes as well as smoked oak wood, cough drops and soy sauce impressions in the finish. Odd and not pleasant. I do love me some smoked beers, but this one just isnt doing it for me. Based on the appearance of the pour, my guess is this bottle is severely past date. Will definitely re-rate when given the opportunity to taste it fresh on draught.

user_location: of Treadwell Park Washington, Washington DC
review_blob: 12oz bottle, bubble pint. Effervescent, clear pale gold pour with a sturdy, frothy white head, which remains at 1 finger thickness until the last sip! Soft, pleasant floral hops accompany a mellow honey and light malt aroma. Flavour is medium sweet and slightly grainy. Authentically Kolsch-like. Aftertaste has good duration for the style and leaves a pleasant impression of light fleshy fruits, apple and sweet grain. This is a solid Kolsch from a solid brewery that very rarely disappoints. Rate to style slutface!

user_location: of Treadwell Park Washington, Washington DC
review_blob: Welp, we have a gusher here. Green glass is wack, btw. Pours a translucent gold colour with a rocky white head, leaving globs of lace (it was a gusher, so not really winning points for that alone). The nose has a profile that borders on a Munchen Helles, an American Pale wheat, and a Belgian Single. Grassy, noble hop aroma, herbal and a bit of lightly zesty orange citrus. Possibly a bit of skunk aroma. The flavour is sweet up front, estery and bready with loads of cereal grain in the finish. Finish is short and boring, with mostly cereal grain notes coming through, much akin to most macro lagers. Almost comes across like cheap plastics. I would easily take this over those macro beers, but this is supposed to be a witbier?! Doesnt taste or smell much like one. This should be classified as a wheat ale. Low overall score due to gushing. Must re-rate when in NZ. The turbulence from the shipment can cause gushing, indirectly.

user_location: of Treadwell Park Washington, Washington DC
review_blob: Snifter. 12oz split with a friend. Nearly black with ruby edges. Minimal head. No retention. Aroma of chestnuts, walnut, brown sugar and tasty wort. The flavour is sweet up front, dry in the finish. Poundable session beer with medium carbonation and a thin, silken palate. Flawless for the style. Cant complain about any aspect, really, and this is a style I appreciate very much.

user_location: of Treadwell Park Washington, Washington DC
review_blob: Pours a nearly opaque tangerine colour with a frothy white head that fades to a thin film and ring. The aroma is estery and uber tropical with potent pineapple, impressions of apricot, savory wheat, and other stone fruits. The flavour is not as intense as the aroma might suggest, but refreshing, fruity (like fruit roll-up fruity), and slightly boozy, which is concerning considering the 5.5% abv. As a summer slammer, this is top notch. As a savory sipper, its a bit thin-bodied and the finish is too short.

user_location: of Treadwell Park Washington, Washington DC
review_blob: 12oz bottle. Bubble pint. Clear rust colour with a thin soapy off-white head. Nose is immediately assaulted with sulfur, herbal hops, roasted nuts and burnt toast. Not too pleasant, but altbier tends to be rather harsh. This is by no means an Oktoberfest lager. Or a Marzen. Lackluster flavour. Rather plain amber-ish lager. Not bitter enough to be an alt. Not crushable enough and lacking the noble aroma of an Oktoberfest. Not sure with what they were going for here. "Savory malt profile"? Yea, if dry crackers and stale bread are considered savory, then by all means. DMS is bordering on out-of-control on this one. Mouthfeel is kinda nice. Lively carbonation and a slick texture. Not bad. Either this is a bad batch, or they need to think long and hard about what they are trying to accomplish with this brew.

user_location: of Treadwell Park Washington, Washington DC
review_blob: 12oz. Bubble pint. Literally pours out a pumpkin orange with a minimal, whispy white head. The aroma has a descent representation of the traditional pumpkin pie spices, along with some odd vegetal notes. Thin, hot and spicy. Not pleasing. Does not have the malty backbone needed to support such potent spices. This is not an IPA where we want an attenuated, light base to display the complexities of the overtones. Its a pumpkin ale. I need the total package, and to be like pumpkin pie in a glass, I need some sweetness, some texture and way less prickly carbonation. This seems to be the problem with nearly every pumpkin ale out there. The finish is short, thin, grainy and uninspired. I mean, its not a bad beer, but based on the label and my expectations, I need more ooomfffff! LI deserves a better pumpkin ale.

user_location: of Treadwell Park Washington, Washington DC
review_blob: 12oz flute. Pours brilliantly clear straw colour with a foamy, whispy white head that somehow leaves good concentric rings of lacing. Aroma suggests floral, herbal hops and subtle cereal grainy, light malt sweetness. Good bitterness right off the bat, and very dry in the finish, leaving me wanting another sip as soon as its gone. The hoppy bouquet is pleasing to say the least. Bright, vibrant, absent of all sulfur compounds, or below my threshold at least. Not grassy, no misplaced dankness or musty earthiness. Just bright, clean bitter and floral hops. Finish leaves me wanting a little more malt, but thats my only complaint. Fizzy carbonation, light bodied and has a long residence time for slightly astringent bitterness. Light, almost airy texture. One of the best summer slammers out there. Had to go for this with the recent resurgence of hot temps here in the hell hole some call the Mid-Atlantic states. RATE TO STYLE esse!

user_location: of Treadwell Park Washington, Washington DC
review_blob: 17oz bottle at Sen in Sag Harbor, NY. Pint glass (unfortunately). Pours a brilliant clear straw colour with a frothy, yet short-lived head. Minimal lacing. The aroma is simialr to a good Munich Helles with slightly less sulfury notes. Sweet grainy malt and flowery/grassy noble hop aroma is well executed. The flavour is equally intense on the noble aroma. Softy sweet malt graces and leaves the palate shortly after. Extremely dry and crushable. Mouthfeel is extremely spritzy  and slightly watery, but thats what the style is about so a high score for this perfectly executed pale lager is appropriate. Bomb titties crushable. A perfect refresher to have with sashimi.

user_location: of Treadwell Park Washington, Washington DC
review_blob: 12oz bottle poured into a snifter. 72.51 IBU, 9.4%abv. Clear, radiant orange pour with a frothy off-white head leaving a dense sheet of lacing on the opposite side of the glass. The nose. Bright candied citrus notes with and toasty, caramel malts and grassy, slightly herbal hops. The flavours do little to hide the 9.4% abv as the beer comes across extremely hot with the first sip. The aftertaste is medicinally, astringently bitter. The sweetness and bitterness together do not balance well and create a combination resembling cough syrup. Some nice citrus notes and bubblegum yeast flavours are trying to come through, but are impeded by astringency and fusel alcohol. Nothing hear melds and the overall package is astringent, hot, and confused. Viciously over-hopped in what is basically a double IPA fermented with Belgian yeast. Grotesquely fusely and possibly oxidized. Thin, syrupy body. At least its cheap, but this is a drain-pour for me. This IS NOT in any way a Belgian strong ale.
beer_name: Lagunitas A Little Sumpin Wild Ale

user_location: of Treadwell Park Washington, Washington DC
review_blob: Batch 1, bitch! Pours a brilliant, clear straw colour, offensively effervescent, and has the rockiest, whitest head Ive EVER seen. Holy tits! I swear a gorilla nipple is popping out of my glass. Glob-a-dob-a-ding-dong lacing. The aroma stinks of the loveliest mildewy flowers. Spruce tips and some subdued zest in the nose as well. Tart, zesty, sprucey flavour with a nice, cheesy lactic tang. Minimal barrel character, but it would not really benefit from too much oak. Spritzy (but not abrasive) and thin bodied, yet velvety mouthfeel. Wet stone. Make a better sour wit than this. You wont!

user_location: of Treadwell Park Washington, Washington DC
review_blob: Pours visibly flat, murky mahogany colour. Nose is tannic and insanely malty perceivable far above the glass. Suggestions of chocolate almond spread, tannic oak, a bit bourbon, and banana bread. Flavour is a bit hot and oaky as f@#&!!!! Nutty aftertaste, mostly almond and walnut with some hints of brown sugar-coated pecans. This is an indulgent malt bomb fer sher. Sweet with just enough heat not to be too cloying. Palate is silken, with a long duration, coating tooth and gum. Very full-bodied.
beer_name: Kuhnhenn Fourth Dementia (4D) Old Ale - Bourbon Barrel

user_location: of Treadwell Park Washington, Washington DC
review_blob: Ive been a huge fan of this series since its inception and am stoked to drink this 750ml to the face! Pours a hazy straw/gold colour with a foamy white head that diminishes quickly to a pencil-thin thin ring. The nose is beautifully complex, allowing the nuances of peach, other stone fruits, the barrel tannins and the tart, funky aromas. There is still noticeable coriander, and wheaty goodness coming through in the aroma as well. This is very tart, but not like a Girandin Black Label gueuze of Hanssens lambic. The tartness has a mix of acetic acidity as well as lactic. Peach and apricot flavours meld harmoniously with tart, sharp, cheesy notes. The palate is thin, a bit slick, crisp and quenching. Its insanely dry in the finish, keeping my coming back for more sicks with increasing frequency. Perhaps it is a bit too highly carbonated for my tastes, which is why I cannot give the palate perfect score. Very refreshing, spritzy, and puckering drink that is not overwhelmingly sour. Phenomenal sour ale that deserves higher marks. This beer has received unfairly low marks within its style. A beer is allowed to be fruity and thin bodied and not violently sour, especially when intentionally.

user_location: of Treadwell Park Washington, Washington DC
review_blob: Small soapy tan head sits atop a clear orange/brown body. Minimal, spotty lacing . The nose is ripe with all those familiar pumpkin pie spices and some pumpkin flesh. First sip was unexpectedly sweet, though absolutely delicious! Notes of Graham cracker accompany an intense, yet drinkable pumpkin pie profile in the finish. Medium/short palate duration is made up for by a slightly slick, medium/full mouthfeel that gives this pumpkin brewhaha the oooomph it needs to be considered a great pumpkin ale, imo. I love pumpkin beers and this is now one of my faves. Thanks, Schlafly!

user_location: of Treadwell Park Washington, Washington DC
review_blob: 12oz bottle poured into a bubble pint. Beautiful clear, effervescent copper pour with a puffy off-white head with great retention. The nose is rather bland with only a few millimeters head left. Distant grapefruit citrus, bready malt, tin and touch of pine needle. Not enthused. Flavour is equally boring and mild. Not much of an IPA, IMO. More of a classic American pale, and a dull one at that. Soapy and slightly metallic notes accompany. The only thing truly going for this beer is the lacing and brilliant copper colour. I usually love everything from the Exit series and most of the seasonals, but this is major dud from an otherwise impressive brewery. Sorry guys, I know youre better than this! Peep my other Flying Fish ratings...
beer_name: Flying Fish HopFish India Pale Ale

user_location: of Treadwell Park Washington, Washington DC
review_blob: 2009 12oz bottle. Slightly cloudy deep mahogany pour with little to no head. Nose of prune, green apple, fig, typical vinous malts, and a hint of tobacco. The aroma is rather soft and unoffensive in its age, which is rare of fresh barley wines. The booze is well masked. The flavour is much of what Id expect given the aromas present. Syrupy sweet, but not cloying. Most of the hop bitterness has completely subsided. Flavours of sherry/Maderia, plum, green apple and a whisper of cocoa. A drying, slightly alcoholic finish is lingers for some time. A bit thin-bodied for a barley wine, in my opinion, but I still love this beer. It was a go-to for me in college and still a comfort beer. Not so great fresh, but what barley wine is? Overall, this is a mellow, rounded barley wine that makes a great night cap. Best had 2-3 years aged at room temperature. The 08 was better, but I do not have that in front of me right now. The deScription sells short its shelf-life.
beer_name: Flying Dog Horn Dog Barley Wine

user_location: of Treadwell Park Washington, Washington DC
review_blob: Lush, hazy red clay colour with a sudsy beige head that leaves globs of lacing. The aroma is worty and earthy with undertones of pine resin. Other nuances of doughy malt, caramel, and sweet yams come to mind. The flavour is equally worty but with more bitterness than can be perceived in the aroma. The hop character is muted, but the hop bitterness remains. This is indicative of an old bottle, therefore I cannot truly attest to the fresh hoppy flavour this beer may have closer to its born-on date.   The hop character I can pick out is of soft citrus, typical of centennial hops. Booze is not hidden so well for 5.8% abv. The mouthfeel is silky, yet is thin-medium bodied. Medium palate duration with some bitterness and caramel malt lingering. I wish I could have tried this fresher.

user_location: of Treadwell Park Washington, Washington DC
review_blob: On draft at the most excellent bar ever, Churchkey DC. More like a Czech pils to me. Full-bodied and malty, yet quenching. The noble hop character is so.....noble! Lasting grassy, herbal hops on this finish. Sweetness is rather high for a German Pils, but thats just fine by me. With an OG of 15.8 plato and only 5.2% abv, no wonder its so syrupy sweet.

user_location: of Treadwell Park Washington, Washington DC
review_blob: A bit pricey at $15 for an 11.2oz. Poured into a snifter. Pours a hazy translucent sunset orange colour with a sudsy white head that dimples as it fades, leaving a solid one-finger cap. A thin, yet complete film of off-white foam is left on the opposite side of the glass. Spotty lacing on the other side. The nose is spicy, floral and funky with an unmistakable french oak and white grape character. Citrus tones resemble pineapple and blood orange. Musty basement aromas give it a "rustic" feel. Flavour is wildly different than the nose suggests. Farmhouse funk, herbal, grassy hops and intense oaky Chardonnay notes dominate. The aftertaste is far less abrasive, leaving little hop impression and much more fruity and vanilla-oak impressions, with a bit of cream-like flavour and a strange suggestion of cinnamon. Lightly sweet, low bitterness and salty.  The mouthfeel features a highly attenuated, thin bodied, yet creamy texture with lively carbonation, and drying finish. The palate duration is long, leaving oaky and yeasty aromatics that linger. Still, this lovely brew coats tooth and gum while feeling dry in the finish. Alcohol is not so well-hidden, but complements the complex nuances this beer has to offer. Outstanding. I dont want this to end!
beer_name: Stillwater Barrel Aged Series - Stateside Saison

user_location: of Treadwell Park Washington, Washington DC
review_blob: An outstanding representation of the style and a go-to slammer for me. Brilliant, clear, deep warm gold colour with a soapy white head. The nose is clean and malty with pleasant cereal grain, and sweet bready, light malt. The flavour is lightly malty and quenching with a barely-perceivable floral hop character and doughy light malt finish. The mouthfeel is on the full side for the style, yet still finishes dry enough to make you want to re-coat your mouth with is quenching, sweet malty goodness.

user_location: of Treadwell Park Washington, Washington DC
review_blob: 22oz bomber -> snifter. Pours a visibly thin deep walnut brown with a short-lived tan head that fades to a wimpy ring. some spotty, thin lacing. The nose is exploding with refined, mature raspberry and mocha notes. Like the finest raspberry dark chocolate truffles Ive ever had the pleasure of savoring. Fruity medium/light roasted coffee is also apparent in the aroma. The flavour has everything I hoped it would, which is everything present in the aroma. A long palate duration leaves a lingering of delicate roast and sweet raspberry/cocoa. The finish is really bone dry, which is not a characteristic I usually like paired with any sort of roasty, sweet beer. If dry is what they were going for, then they nailed it. Certainly thin-bodied, which is understandable at 4.6%, but still, a fuller palate would make this beer absolutely phenomenal. Maybe its not as thin-bodied as the finish is dry. Bone fuggin dry, yet there is still a nice lingering of the aforementioned flavours.  Some spruce-like hops tastefully counter the sweetness. Will definitely buy again for friends and family and would love to try this on tap.

user_location: of Treadwell Park Washington, Washington DC
review_blob: I hate all things corporate, so the label sold me. 22oz bomber poured a full pint into a Sam Smiths bubble pint. Glowing rustic orange colour, hazy, with a sudsy beige head that fades to a thin film. Nice lacing. The nose has citric hops, mostly faint lemon and some pine, which in combination with the massive caramel malt impression, comes off smelling like tropical citrus fruits. Candy sweet caramel/cotton candy flavour with subdued hops, but still very nice citric notes coming through just enough to be considered an APA. In the finish and aftertaste a very unexpected vanilla and biscuit flavour emerges and lingers for sometime, later lending way to mixed citrus fruits again. I have no explanation for what that could be from, but Im into it! Syrupy mouthfeel almost puts this in the traditional ale category. This is seriously unexpected. As it warms, orange citrus, peach and kiwi flavours surface. This is a very complex, pleasing, malt bomb of an APA.  As Im much of a malt head as a hop head, this was no disappointment to me. Cali IPA drinkers will not like this, but who cares, theyre so one-dimensional with what they expect from their hoppy ales. Overall - of this I approve! fuck commerce!!!

user_location: of Treadwell Park Washington, Washington DC
review_blob: Great clarity, colour intensity and head retention on this one, as well as concentric rings of lacing. The aroma is fresh, floral hops, butterscotch, doughy malts, and straightforward light maltiness. An earthier hop presence shines in the flavour along with nutty malt impressions (Munich malt, perhaps), a whisper of cocoa and a hint of old coffee. Straightforward beer style done right. Full-bodied for the style with gentle yet, tingly carbonation and a medium/long palate duration. This is proof that an organic ale can stand up to the rest of em. As this is a year-round beer, I must imagine that being organic, the spec on the malts will have slightly more variation in their specs, which might in turn mean the recipe must be tweaked with each brew to compensate, making it a bitch to brew (or not). I give Laurelwood tons of credit for helping lift doubts about beers produced from organic malts. I doubt the hops are organic, but if they are, even more kudos. Goes great with simple pub food and a go to session beer for me when living the dream of the 90s in Portlandia. This was my favorite amber and still may be. Rate to style, haters!

user_location: of Treadwell Park Washington, Washington DC
review_blob: Hazy, but not opaque sunset orange colour that is visibly viscous. The head fades quickly, but leaves some spotty lace. The nose is dominated by caramel, grapefruit, light pine resin, and lightly toasty malts. The booze is masked well in the aroma. Not as hoppy as I remember, which is why you should never ship IPAs unless refrigerated for the entirety of its journey. The flavour is bitter, but not super hoppy. Again, dont ship IPAs! Grapefruity NW hops and caramel maltiness. Very straight-forward, but also very pleasant and drinkable considering the high abv. Fuller-bodied than others, which is nice, as well as long palate duration that leaves a piney, grapefruit impression. Not that great over hear on the beast cost, but fresh I remember this being way better. Will definitely re-rate at some point.

user_location: of Treadwell Park Washington, Washington DC
review_blob: Pours a nearly opaque amber colour with a sudsy off-white head that leaves dense spotty lacing. The aroma is a righteous bouquet of pine, resin, orange zest,  flowery hops and vinous, caramel-like malts. Im detecting slight oxidation, as there is a sherry component here, but this is certainly due to the cross-country shipping in the summer heat. Ive had it fresh at the brewpub and that certainly was not detectable there. It kinda feels like a mild barley wine, but Im not complaining, I dig it. The flavour is extremely bitter, citric and resinous with just the right amount of chewy, caramel-like malt character to back it up. The finish is a bit boozier that the abv might suggest, but its still incredibly drinkable for a 100 IBU destroyer of senses. The mouthfeel is full and slick with prickly carbonation piercing through the chewiness. For the price, this is a good everyday bomber, for sure.

user_location: of Treadwell Park Washington, Washington DC
review_blob: Shipped from OR mid-summer, so this rating will be compromised. I will give it the benefit of the doubt, nonetheless. Pours a pale, hazy orange cream colour with a soapy off-white head that fades to a thin film, leaving spotty lacing. The nose is as malty as it is hoppy. The aroma brings impressions of chewy caramel, citrus flesh, subdued resin, and some heat as it warms. Flowery hops, citrus flesh again, orange creamsickle, sherry, some resin and very mild pine. Silky mouthfeel, fine carbonation that is on the softer side. Nice balance for a west-coast ipa, where they usually tend toward over-attenuated hop bombs with no body. Long palate duration with emphasis on the citrus. Stellar.
beer_name: Hop Valley Alpha Centauri Binary IPA

user_location: of Treadwell Park Washington, Washington DC
review_blob: Uneventful uncorking of this 12.7oz cork/caged lambic. It appears completely flat, with a brilliant, clear Merlot colour. The aroma emanates far from the glass with rich, sugary cherry pie notes gracing the schnoz. Some mild barnyard funk and swampy mineral notes in the background with closer examination. Completely flat. The flavour is intoxicates the palate with sour red cherry, leather and some cheesy funk. Not as much depth as other fruit lambics Ive encountered. Not worth the $27 at my local bottle shop.

user_location: of Treadwell Park Washington, Washington DC
review_blob: 22oz bomber. Poured into a 16oz snifter, moderate pour produces a short-lived, yet dense mocha head with an opaque black body. No lacing whatsoever. The nose is wildly complex, rich and deep with very strong tones of anise (black licorice), oak/vanilla and gram cracker with impressions of spruce, cocoa, roast and estery yeast. The flavour is not as pleasant as the nose is, as I like the aroma of these ingredients better than their accompanying flavours. The anise is so prominent, its bordering on offensive, but its named in the title of the brand so I guess I got what I signed up for. Impressions of vanilla, baking cocoa and oak round it out a bit. The aftertaste is the most pleasing part of this beer IMHO. The overall package is rather sophisticated for how extreme it is. Its not as abrasive as I had anticipated. The Belgian yeast is dominated by the roasted malt, anise and oak flavours, but I think thats a good thing. For such a mash-up, I find this to be relatively drinkable and enjoyable, as I find myself taking shorter and shorter pauses in between sips as it warms. I can taste the fusel alcohols, though, and I know its going to be a serious bitch getting to work at 7 tomorrow! The mouthfeel suggests a reasonable level of attenuation, being medium/thin bodied for the style. Its airy, like most beers fermented with Belgian yeast. Hot and spicy (not pepper spicy) lingering accompanies the roast.
beer_name: Stone Imperial Russian Stout - Belgo Anise
